repnme.cdata!:
Mozambique - First National Water
            Development Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The outcome for the First National Water
            Development Project for Mozambique was satisfactory, the
            sustainability was likely, the institutional development
            impact was substantial, and the Bank and borrower
            performance were both satisfactory. Lessons learned from the
            project: The problems faced at the beginning of the project
            emphasize the need for thorough project preparation and
            design. A great deal of effort is needed, in terms of time,
            expense and expertise, to establish the necessary platform
            of reformed policy, legislation, and guidelines to ensure
            the success of processes such as introducing private sector
            participation into urban water service provision, shifting
            to a demand responsive approach in rural water, and
            establishing a water resources strategy. The impact of and
            need for strong project management, good departmental
            leadership and political support in such reform / pioneering
            projects cannot be overemphasized.

Mozambique - First National Water

5081349.majtheme: Financial and private sector development,Environment and natural resource management,Rural development,Urban development

repnme.cdata!: Mozambique - National Water Development I Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The National Water Development I Project
            seeks to increase the capacities of the organizations and
            people of the sector, and prepare for the private sector
            management of the urban water supply systems of five cities
            (Maputo, Beira, Quelimane, Nampula and Pemba), so that
            sector organizations can provide sustainable water supply
            and sanitation services to an increasing proportion of the
            community and manage water resources sustainably. There are
            five components in this project. First, institution building
            and policy development will develop a regulatory and
            monitoring framework and capacity, and undertake studies for
            development of water sector policy. Second, preparation for
            private sector management of urban water supply will support
            the bidding process for the private sector management of the
            water supply systems of the five cities, design and
            construct emergency works, prepare plans for the provision
            of sanitation services in the five cities. Third, rural
            water supply and sanitation (RWSS) will reorient and reform
            the management and implementation of RWSS. Fourth, water
            resources management will develop a national water resources
            management strategy. Fifth, human resources development will
            emphasize management training and development.

repnme.cdata!:
Mozambique - National Water Resources
            Management and Development Project : environmental assessment

abstracts.cdata!:
The National Water Development Project
            seeks to improve the management of water resources and
            increase the quality, reliability and coverage of urban and
            rural water supply services, in support of the
            implementation of the National Water Policy. The project has
            three components: i) urban and peri-urban water supply; ii)
            rural water and sanitation; and iii) water resources
            management. This project will involve little resettlements.
            However, the study does provide guidance for future
            resettlement planning, as well as standard environmental
            requirements. During construction, noise, dust and air
            emissions should be minimized by using modern equipment.
            Measures must be taken to prevent oils and chemicals from
            seeping into the ground or into water courses. Used oils and
            lubricants should be collected and disposed out of the
            working area. Trenches should be carefully backfilled to
            avoid later subsidence and erosion. During operation, intake
            water quality should be monitored regularly to minimize the
            risk of unknown substance or minerals adversely affecting
            drinking water. Significant leakage of pipes will cause
            erosion and flooding, and should be prevented by automatic
            monitoring of pressure of flow.
